> Thanks for the clear responses. What i see is that a theory is a
> (parametrized) test inside out; you don't specify what will work but you
> leave out what should not be tested (iow assumptions by leaving out the data
> for these cases).

I'm not sure that there is a misunderstanding here but just to make sure:

While what you wrote is technically true I think it simplifies the
theory a bit. I would consider a long list of assumptions in a theory
a smell, perhaps named: "assmumptions is the mother of all screw ups"
:). I almost fell into the trap of using assumptions to filter the
"desired" datapoints to the "correct" theory but that would be a
violation of the idea, the idea is that the datapoints I have
specified and all other datapoints I (or an automatic tool) can come
up with should pass. I think that there is a subtle difference here
between data driven tests and theories, data driven tests are merely a
convenient way to create lots of specific examples while theories aim
at the abstraction, the definition of the truth in this system.

If a lot of assumptions are a smell, then what are our weapons against
them? I found that declaring types help here and it pays off
instantly. For instance, if I represent name as a String and phone
number as a String and it is important to my theories to differentiate
between the two I could ether:

Assume that any string with numbers in it is a phone number and that
anything that is not a phone number is a name.
Or, I could declare the type Name and the type PhoneNumber.

In this case I would prefer a type.

If I was intersted in defining what a long distance call is I could
write that as a theory:

 @Theory
public void makeLongDistanceCall(PhoneNumber from, PhoneNumber to) {
     assumeThat(from.areaCode, is(not(equalTo(to.areaCode)));
     Call call = new Call(from, to);
     assertTrue(call.isLongDistance());
}

I probably screwed up both the domain and the design but I hope my
idea of what an assumptions role in a theory is and how theories are
different than data-driven tests in spite of them both being driven by
data.
I also hope that in the case the domain is screwed up it should be
perfectly clear from the above theory to anyone who knows the domain.
Finally, I hope this helps someone :)
